title: Program encourages girls to pursue careers in science, technology - NorthJersey.com
text:
Program encourages girls to pursue careers in science, technology September 21, 2015 Last updated: Monday, September 21, 2015, 10:45 AM By Kimberly Redmond Buy this photo Photo courtesy of elaine zheng The program, Girls Who Code, was offered for the first time ever in New Jersey, thanks to support from the Verizon Foundation, and gave girls like Elaine Zheng, a junior at Northern Highlands Regional High School, a chance to delve more into computer sciences. 
Although science and technology have historically been male-dominated fields, women employed in those industries are working to encourage girls not to shy away from pursuing more technical careers. 
This past summer, more than three dozen girls received mentoring from women in those fields during an intensive seven-week, 300-hour program held at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark, where they learned computing, mobile app development, graphics, animation, web development, and web design. 
The program, Girls Who Code, was offered for the first time ever in New Jersey, thanks to support from the Verizon Foundation, and gave girls like Elaine Zheng, a junior at Northern Highlands Regional High School, a chance to delve more into computer sciences. 
"My favorite part of the program was the environment. I had taken an intro to computer science class previously and the gender ratio in my class was about one girl for every five guys. Not only was it encouraging to be in a room full of girls as passionate and interested in STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) as I was, but it was also a great learning environment," Zheng said. 
"It was amazing to be with other girls who came from a variety of backgrounds but came together with one common interest - STEM," she said, adding that it was a bonding experience. 
"In my school, there are some girls who are interested in STEM subjects but I think overall, in high schools all around, there is a sizeable gender gap in almost every STEM-related class," said the Upper Saddle River teen. 
During the Girls Who Code program, the Verizon Foundation encouraged its senior female leaders to participate as a way to help motivate girls to continue their education and consider STEM-related careers. 
Rose Kirk, president of the Verizon Foundation, said, "This change begets opportunity. Our society is becoming more diverse in its race, its thinking and its power - and technology is at the nexus of innovation." 
Kirk said "smart, determined, young women" are "the change our society needs" and "the change companies in America - like Verizon - need also." 
According to a report from the U.S. Department of Commerce's Economic and Statistics Administration, women "are vastly underrepresented in STEM jobs and among STEM degree holders, despite making up nearly half of the U.S. workforce." 
Women hold less than 25 percent of STEM jobs, despite holding half of all jobs in the economy, the report says. By 2020, there will be 1.4 million jobs available in computing and technical fields, but women in the U.S. are only on track to filling 3 percent of those positions. 
The main mission of Girls Who Code, a national non-profit, is to close those gaps in industries related to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. 
Zheng said she's looking at colleges with a focus on computer science, as well as graphic design to possibly double major in the two and is forming a Girls Who Code Club at her school, along with two other classmates who attended the program this summer. 
"I'm interested in all sorts of STEM related careers. UX (User Experience) as well as UI (User Interface) design have been two career options that have interested me as they are a way to combine my interest in the arts as well as my interest in computer science," she said. "In the future I would also love to inspire other girls to program, like Girls Who Code and our speakers did for me."
